title: This comment refers to the fact that children in England at this time were generally schooled in French and Latin rather than English. It was not until after the Plague (1348-50) that English became a language of instruction in grammar schools, but there is evidence from c. 1250 on of a decreased native familiarity with French. Around this time a number of manuals for learning French circulated and, later in the century, monasteries and universities had to legislate students' use of French or Latin rather than English in daily conversations
